column26: I am currently enrolled in a course with 150+ people, the room is incapable of fitting that amount, however about 30% of the class either attend the lecture online since it is hybrid, or do not attend at all. Additionally, I'm also enrolled in a course with about 100 students with one lab session a week and although the two lab rooms are used for that session, it is impossible for everyone to attend due to size, having multiple sessions for this would help.

column26: I have 0 problems with large classes as they tend to have more flexible lecture and tutorial times than smaller classes. The only problem is when they get full and you have to get an override or choose the course the next academic year or semester.
I have found that my larger classes have been courses that are year 1 prerequisites across many programmes, affecting the large size.

column21: Changed my mind about doing it
column24: Suffer

column19: The content was the same, though the teaching space was different. Probably since both repeats were done in the summer with a smaller class size.

I repeated a course both during summer and the school year. Both were core courses with over 100 students and had labs and tutorials. Both courses had 2 lecture groups.

The one I repeated in summer had roughly 80-90 people enrolled but an attendance of ~50 (so it felt much smaller). There were no labs and the syllabus was much more condensed, omitting a few things and paying less attention to others.

The one I repeated during the school year had roughly the same size (as far as i could tell) and lecture sizes (although started with a full room), dwindled to around 60-100 students. The labs are relatively the same size, though the tutor changed. I had a different lecturer compared to year prior as well, although I stayed in the 'group 1' time slot. The content was relatively the same.
column24: I had to choose a different class stream

column19: I repeated the course during summer, so usually large class was considerably smaller, and so, class space was larger, and course content was more concise and understandable.
column24: I chose a class with a different time slot
column26: Honestly, I do enjoy large classes. In a way, it comforts me to know that I'm not in this alone. With regards to teaching, I find that it's much nicer to just sit and listen to what the professor is communicating, rather than having smaller, interactive classes. I do learn quite a lot in smaller classes, since it's easier to ask questions and engage in discussions, but I learn a lot as well in large classes, too, unless the course content is not appealing enough to hold my attention (in the case of being a necessary core course, but, for instance, being based more on another subject than the subject I am interested in).
